revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

Orthodox Church]]}} | canonized_place = | canonized_by = | major_shrine = [[Church of All Saints, Yekaterinburg|Church on Blood]], Yekaterinburg, Russia | suppressed_date = | issues = }} '''Nicholas II''' or '''Nikolai II Alexandrovich Romanov'''{{efn|{{lang-rus|Николай II Александрович Романов|r=Nikolay II Aleksandrovich Romanov|p=nʲɪkɐˈlaj ftɐˈroj ɐlʲɪkˈsandrəvʲɪtɕ rɐˈmanəf|links=yes}}; spelled {{lang|ru|Александровичъ Романовъ}} in [[Reforms of Russian orthography|pre-revolutionary script]].}} ({{OldStyleDateNY|18 May|6 May}} 1868{{spnd}}17 July 1918), known in the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] as '''Saint Nicholas the Passion-Bearer''',{{efn|{{lang-rus|Святой страстотерпец Николай|r=Svyatoy strastoterpets Nikolay|p=svʲɪˈtoj strəstɐˈtʲerpʲɪts nʲɪkɐˈlaj|}}.}} was the last [[Emperor of Russia]], [[Congress Poland|King of Congress Poland]] and [[Grand Duke of Finland]], ruling from 1 November 1894 until [[Abdication of Nicholas II|his abdication]] on 15 March 1917. During his reign, Nicholas gave support to the economic and political reforms promoted by his prime ministers, [[Sergei Witte]] and [[Pyotr Stolypin]]. He advocated modernization based on foreign loans and close ties with France, but resisted giving the new parliament (the [[State Duma (Russian Empire)|Duma]]) major roles.{{cite book|author=Figes, Orlando |title=A People's Tragedy, The Russian Revolution: 1891–1924 |date=1998|publisher=Penguin Books USA|pages=22–23|isbn=978-0-14-024364-2}}{{cite book|author=Longworth, Phillip |title=Russia:The Once and Future Empire From Pre-History to Putin |url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/Russia/4IuBJ-8BG64C?hl=en&gbpv=1&bsq=Nicholas|date=2006|publisher=St. Martin's Press|pages=233|isbn=978-0-312-36041-2}} Ultimately, progress was undermined by Nicholas's commitment to [[autocracy|autocratic rule]],{{cite book|author=Figes, Orlando |title=A People's Tragedy, The Russian Revolution: 1891-1924 |date=1998|publisher=Penguin Books USA|pages=22–23|isbn=978-0-14-024364-2}}{{cite book|author=Longworth, Phillip |title=Russia:The Once and Future Empire From Pre-History to Putin |url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/Russia/4IuBJ-8BG64C?hl=en&gbpv=1&bsq=Nicholas|date=2006|publisher=St. Martin's Press|pages=233|isbn=978-0-312-36041-2}} strong aristocratic opposition and defeats sustained by the Russian military in the [[Russo-Japanese War]] and [[World War I]].{{cite book|author=MacMillan, Margaret |title=The Road to 1914:The War That Ended Peace |date=2014|publisher=Random House Trade Paperbacks |page=176|isbn=978-0-8129-8066-0}}{{cite book|author=Alexander Rabinowitch|title=The Bolsheviks in Power: The First Year of Soviet Rule in Petrograd|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BEoBCGJ4VqYC&pg=PA1|year=2008|publisher=Indiana UP|page=1|isbn=978-0253220424}}{{cite book|author=Willmott, H.P. |title= World War I |date=2003 |publisher=Dorling Kindersley Publishing |page=147 |isbn=0-7894-9627-5}} By March 1917, public support for Nicholas had collapsed and he was forced to abdicate the throne, thereby ending the [[Romanov dynasty]]'s 304-year rule of Russia (1613–1917). Nicholas signed the [[Anglo-Russian Convention]] of 1907, which was designed to counter [[German Empire|Germany]]'s attempts to gain influence in the Middle East; it ended the [[Great Game]] of confrontation between Russia and the [[British Empire]]. He aimed to strengthen the [[Franco-Russian Alliance]] and proposed the unsuccessful [[Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907|Hague Convention of 1899]] to promote disarmament and solve international disputes peacefully.{{Cite web|title=Tsar Nicholas II: Peace and International Jurisdiction {{!}} Peace Palace Library|url=https://www.peacepalacelibrary.nl/library-special/tsar-nicholas-ii-peace-and-international-jurisdiction/|access-date=27 February 2021|language=en-US}} Domestically, he was criticised for his government's repression of political opponents and his perceived fault or inaction during the [[Khodynka Tragedy]], [[Pogroms in the Russian Empire|anti-Jewish pogroms]], [[Bloody Sunday (1905)|Bloody Sunday]] and the violent suppression of the [[1905 Russian Revolution]]. His popularity was further damaged by the Russo-Japanese War, which saw the [[Baltic Fleet|Russian Baltic Fleet]] annihilated at the [[Battle of Tsushima]], together with the loss of Russian influence over Manchuria and Korea and the [[Karafuto Prefecture|Japanese annexation of the south of Sakhalin Island]].{{cite book|author=MacMillan, Margaret |title=The Road to 1914:The War That Ended Peace |date=2014|publisher=Random House Trade Paperbacks |page=176|isbn=978-0-8129-8066-0}} During the [[July Crisis]], Nicholas supported [[Kingdom of Serbia|Serbia]] and approved the mobilization of the [[Imperial Russian Army|Russian Army]] on 30 July 1914. In response, Germany declared war on Russia on 1 August 1914 and its ally France on 3 August 1914,{{cite web |title=World War I Declarations |url=https://www.loc.gov/rr/news/topics/ww1declarations.html |publisher=The Library of Congress |access-date=5 September 2019}} starting the [[World War I|Great War]], later known as the First World War. The severe military losses led to a collapse of morale at the front and at home; a [[general strike]] and a mutiny of the garrison in [[Saint Petersburg|Petrograd]] sparked the [[February Revolution]] and the disintegration of the monarchy's authority. After abdicating for himself and his son, Nicholas and his family were imprisoned by the [[Russian Provisional Government]] and exiled to Siberia. After the [[Bolsheviks]] took power in the [[October Revolution]], the family was held in [[Yekaterinburg]], where they were [[Execution of the Romanov family|executed]] on 17 July 1918.{{cite book|author=Alexander Rabinowitch|title=The Bolsheviks in Power: The First Year of Soviet Rule in Petrograd|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BEoBCGJ4VqYC&pg=PA1|year=2008|publisher=Indiana UP|page=1|isbn=978-0253220424}}{{cite book|author=Willmott, H.P. |title= World War I |date=2003 |publisher=Dorling Kindersley Publishing |page=147 |isbn=0-7894-9627-5}} In 1981, Nicholas, his wife, and their children were recognized as martyrs by the [[Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia]], based in New York City.A Reader's Guide to Orthodox Icons [http://iconreader.wordpress.com/2011/07/17/the-icons-that-canonized-the-holy-royal-martyrs/ ''The Icons that Canonized the Holy Royal Martyrs''] Their gravesite was discovered in 1979, but this was not acknowledged until 1989. After the fall of the [[Soviet Union]], the remains of the imperial family were exhumed, identified by DNA analysis, and re-interred with an elaborate state and church ceremony in St. Petersburg on 17 July 1998, exactly 80 years after their deaths. They were [[Canonization of the Romanovs|canonized]] in 2000 by the Russian Orthodox Church as [[passion bearer]]s.[http://churchmotherofgod.org/orthodox-terminology/glossary-p/495-passion-bearer.html "Orthodox Terminology", Church of the Mother of God]. Churchmotherofgod.org. Retrieved on 5 December 2018. In the years following his death, Nicholas was reviled by [[Historiography in the Soviet Union|Soviet historians]] and [[Propaganda in the Soviet Union|state propaganda]] as a "callous tyrant" who "persecuted his own people while sending countless soldiers to their deaths in pointless conflicts".{{cite book|author=Kallistov, D. P. |title=History of the USSR in Three Parts: From the earliest times to the Great October Socialist Revolution |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qAFBAAAAYAAJ |year=1977 |publisher=Progress Publishers.{{page needed|date=January 2019}}}} Despite being viewed more positively in recent years, the majority view among historians is that Nicholas was a well-intentioned yet poor ruler who proved incapable of handling the challenges facing his nation.{{Cite web|title=Восстановим историческую справедливость!|url=https://xn----7sbbz2c8a3d.xn--p1ai/|access-date=17 February 2021|website=За-Царя.рф|language=ru}}{{cite journal|author=Esthus, Raymond A. |title=Nicholas II and the Russo-Japanese War|journal=Russian Review|volume=40|issue=4|year=1981|pages=396–411|jstor=129919|doi=10.2307/129919}}Ferro, Marc (1995) ''Nicholas II: Last of the Tsars''. New York: Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|0-19-508192-7}}, p. 2{{cite book|author=Warnes, David |title= Chronicle of the Russian Tsars |date=1999 |publisher=Thames And Hudson |page=163 |isbn=0-500-05093-7}}
